Available online 20 March 2023 Review Syntheses and applications of single-atom catalysts for electrochemical energy conversion reactions Qi-Ni Zhan Ting-Yu Shuai Hui-Min Xu Chen-Jin Huang Zhi-Jie Zhang Gao-Ren Li * College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, Sichuan, China College of Materials Science and Engineering Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610065 China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, Sichuan, China * Corresponding author. Singe-atom catalysts (SACs), as heterogeneous catalysts, have attracted increasing attention in recent years owing to their numerous advantages in the field of electrocatalysis, such as a high atom-utilization rate and unique structural characteristics. In this review, we introduce various preparation methods for obtaining SACs based on top-down and bottom-up synthesis strategies and the corresponding research progress made in recent years. We also focus on the electrocatalytic applications of SACs containing noble metals (Pt, Pd, Ir, etc.) and non-noble metals (Fe, Cu, Co, etc.) in the oxygen evolution reaction, hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen reduction reaction, carbon dioxide reduction reaction, and nitrogen reduction reaction. Finally, the future challenges and prospects of monatomic catalysts are also discussed. Graphical Abstract Single-atom catalysts (SACs), a class of heterogeneous catalysts, have many characteristics, such as a high atom utilization rate and unsaturated coordination. In this paper, we focus on the development of preparation methods for obtaining SACs, including top-down and bottom-up approaches, and the application of some SACs in various electrochemical energy conversion reactions in recent years. Keywords Single atom catalyst Electrocatalysis Oxygen evolution reaction Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen reduction reaction CO2 reduction reaction Nitrogen reduction reaction 1 Introduction It is undeniable that the modern-day high-energy consumption modes of life and production have resulted in severe energy depletion and environmental problems over the past decades. Whether it is the indispensable electrical energy required for daily activities or the chemical energy consumed in various industrial preparations, most of the initial energy conversions require the use of a catalyst. Faced with problems such as reducing metal or natural-resource consumptions, reducing toxic gas emissions, and improving energy-conversion efficiencies, the discovery of clean and sustainable energy can undoubtedly solve these challenges [1–4]. Electrocatalysts are key in the development of clean-energy-production processes, and single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted great attention in recent years owing to their excellent catalytic performance, making single-atom catalysis one of the most advanced research fields [5–7]. SACs, as new stars in the field of heterogeneous catalysis, have different characteristics from those of conventional heterogeneous catalysts, with recyclability requirements and low activities, and homogeneous catalysts, with high activities, high selectivities, and low stabilities [8–12]. Owing to their special structure, SACs with the following advantages have become low-cost high-performance catalysts [13–17]. Isolated single atoms are dispersed in SACs to maximize atom utilization, which is beneficial for decreasing metal consumption. Noble metal-based catalysts, such as Pt-based catalysts, often exhibit excellent catalytic performance in electrochemical energy conversion but are limited because of the scarcity of their raw materials and high cost during industrial development. The isolated exposed single-atom active sites on SACs can efficiently utilize each surface Pt atom, which is difficult to react in traditional bulk catalysts and nano-catalysts. SACs are similar to homogeneous catalysts as their active sites and geometric configurations are similar to those of conventional homogeneous catalysts, which is useful for improving catalytic selectivity. The process of electrochemical energy conversion is not always a simple single-path reaction. For example, in the carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), the product stream may contain CO and CH4, with some catalysts realizing three or more products, which makes it difficult to obtain the targeted yield for the desired product. Therefore, highly selective catalysts are required in electrochemical energy conversion applications. Each active site on a SAC plays a consistent role during the catalytic process. This is beneficial for maximizing target product selectivities and yields, which improves the catalytic reaction efficiency. The unsaturated coordination structure and unique electronic structure of SACs increase their intrinsic activities. For example, in the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), Pt is often included in traditional catalysts as an active component to achieve high catalytic performance. On the other hand, more non-noble metal-based SACs are exhibiting performances that are comparable with those of commercial Pt-based catalysts [18–20]. At the same time, Cu-based SACs have been developed for the CO2RR to form specific products. In addition to CO, they are considered for the selective production of C1 (CH4, CH3OH, etc.) and C2 (C2H4, C2H5OH, etc.) products [21–24]. The simple and uniform structure of SACs enables the study of the active sites, catalytic mechanism, as well as the design and modification of catalyst synthesis methods. In the synthesis of some SACs, the stability of the catalyst can be significantly improved by designing coordination points, carrier vacancy defects, and anchoring points for the single atoms in the space of porous materials to enhance the interaction between metal single atoms and their carriers [25–36]. In terms of electrochemical energy conversion, the development of SACs of low cost, low metal consumption, and high electrocatalytic performance has become a very promising direction. An increasing number of studies has shown that SACs have excellent catalytic performance in various electrochemical energy conversion reactions when compared with traditional catalysts, but there still exists some problems, including low metal loadings and low catalyst stability. The main cause of these problems is the isolated and homogeneous arrangement of the single-atom active sites in SACs. A single atom can theoretically maximize the atom-utilization rate of a SAC to 100%, but the high surface free energy leads to the easy agglomeration of the metal single atoms in SACs. To improve the stability of the catalyst, the common solution is to reduce the loading of metal active sites on the carrier, which limits catalytic activity. Catalyst design and synthesis have a great impact on catalytic performance. The isolated single-atom sites in SACs are the most distinctive feature; therefore, the uniform and stable anchoring of single atoms on the carrier are key synthesis factors. To achieve these goals, it is necessary to effectively inhibit agglomeration and the formation of nanoparticles [37]. Simultaneously, the balance between metal loading and SAC stability also needs more research attention, in other words, trying to find ways to ensure a good stability at high loadings. After the concept of SACs was proposed by Zhang and colleagues [38], a variety of SAC synthesis methods have been designed and applied, including electrochemical deposition, atomic-layer deposition, space refinement, and flame-spray pyrolysis. In this paper, we systematically review the research and applications of SACs in terms of their preparation and electrocatalytic performance in recent years. Regarding SAC synthesis, we have divided the synthesis methods into top-down and bottom-up synthesis strategies and described the two classes of SAC preparation. We then discuss the applications and performances of traditional catalyst synthesis methods (such as impregnation and co-precipitation) and emerging methods (such as spatial confinement and in situ pyrolysis) in the two categories. We also introduce the application of SACs in five electrochemical energy conversion reactions, namely, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), HER, ORR, CO2RR, and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), and highlight their superior performance in terms of catalytic activity, stability, selectivity, and kinetics in the abovementioned reactions. Finally, we put forward the prospects for the problems and development of SACs. 2 Preparation of single-atom catalysts As emerging catalysts with great prospects, SACs have attracted wide attention owing to their attractive properties in the field of catalysis [39]. Because of high surface energy, single atoms easily agglomerate during catalyst synthesis [40]. In recent years, numerous methods have been developed for the preparation of SACs, such as traditional wet chemical methods, atomic-layer deposition, high-temperature atomic migration capture, and the spatial confinement strategy [41–44]. These preparation methods can be divided into two categories: bottom-up and top-down strategies [31,45]. Bottom-up strategies often require mononuclear metal complexes as starting precursors, which are precipitated and dispersed on a selected carrier to restrict the defects of the carrier while forming stable metal single atoms. Bottom-up strategies include wet chemical methods, atomic-layer deposition, defect design, and the spatial confinement strategy [32,46–53]. Unlike bottom-up strategies, the starting precursors of top-down strategies are metal nanoparticles or bulk metals. These top-down strategies are often performed at high temperatures to form strong bonds between the single-atom metals and their carriers to hinder the atom agglomeration and maintain single-atom isolation. Various top-down synthesis strategies have been developed in recent years, such as high-temperature atomic migration capture, in situ pyrolysis, and flame-spray pyrolysis [54]. 2.1 Bottom-up synthesis strategies To ensure atomic dispersion, the active metal loading needs to be reduced and an adequate distance between the active metal atoms needs to be maintained. However, catalysts with low metal loadings tend to exhibit low catalytic performances [31]. Moreover, the uncertainty of the vacancy defects in the carrier makes it difficult to accurately control the synthesized SAC structure. To solve these problems, it is necessary to select appropriate metal precursors and carriers. When the coordination species, vacancy defects, or pore structure of the carrier are anchored to the metal precursor, they will play the role of inhibiting atom agglomeration and stabilizing the dispersed metal atoms [55]. In SAC preparation, wet chemical methods generally include impregnation, co-precipitation, precipitation-deposition, and electrochemical deposition. 2.1.1 Impregnation method Impregnation is a convenient method for preparing SACs. In this method, the support is mixed with the aqueous solution of the metal precursor, so that the metal atoms of the precursor are fixed on the support through adsorption or restriction. Thereafter, the solution is removed through a series of steps, and the dried product is recovered. Wu and co-workers reported that Pt atoms were adsorbed on hierarchical nitrogen-doped carbon nanocages (hNCNC) using a simple impregnation-adsorption method [56]. In this experiment, the researchers added the H2PtCl6·6H2O solution to distill water to disperse hNCNC, and then stirred, washed, and dried the material at 70 °C to obtain Pt/hNCNC SACs. The metal loading in the SACs was optimized by changing the amount of H2PtCl6·6H2O in solution. The disappearance of the Pt–Pt peak at approximately 2.55 Å in their extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum and the right shift of the pyridinic N peak in their X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) indicated the synergistic effect of nitrogen doping on the single Pt atoms, which effectively increased the ability of the support surface to capture and disperse Pt atoms. Because of the limited number of defects and functional groups provided by the support for the adsorption or restriction of metal atoms, it was still difficult to produce SACs with a high metal loading. To maximize the catalytic performance of SACs, the impregnation method needs to be optimized. PtGa-Pb metal SACs, which are Pt-based catalysts supported on SiO2, were prepared by Furukawa et al. [57] via co-impregnation. The catalysts exhibited good selectivity and activity during propylene dehydrogenation (PDH). In preparing the catalysts, considering the two elements to improve the PDH performance, the use of Pt and Cr2O3, and the balance between the propylene desorption rate and the undesirable side reactions, the researchers included metallic Pb to modify PtGa to eliminate the presence of threefold Pt atoms in the catalyst, which made the C–H (C) splitting process more facile during PDH [58–61]. Simultaneously, the special structure of PtGa and the deposition of Pb to obtain single-atom Pt sites (Fig. 3(a) ) limited the presence of Pt–Pt compositions that are capable of catalyzing side reactions (e.g., over dehydrogenation and hydrogenolysis). In the experiment, the SiO2 substrate was added in solution via co-precipitation. After sealing, rapid cooling, drying at 90 °C, and calcining at 400 °C, the mixture was reduced in a H2 atmosphere for 1 h to obtain the catalyst. Combining high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) with density functional theory (DFT) calculations, it was concluded that a propane dehydrogenation catalyst with isolated single Pt atoms was successfully prepared (Figs. 3(b) and 3(c)). In the Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and DFT simulation results, PtGa-Pb/SiO2 only showed a band at 2050 cm−1, which was for CO adsorption, further proving that threefold Pt was selectively blocked by Pb. The researchers also prepared Ga-Pb/SiO2 for comparison to exclude the influence of Ga on the PDH reaction, and the DFT calculation of the free energy change of propane conversion in the PDH reaction, the third highest C–H splitting free energy verified the selectivity of single Pt atoms to propylene in the catalytic process (Fig. 3(d)). Fig. 1 The development and future applications of single atom catalysts. Fig. 2 The unique properties of single atom catalysts. By changing the sites of Zn and La, Du and co-workers [62] prepared ZnLa-1/CN SACs via impregnation. The catalyst preparation was performed on a melamine sea surface, and the precursor metal nitrate solution mixed with urea was immersed into the sponge to make it saturated. After rapid cooling, drying, and annealing at 550 °C in a N2 atmosphere, Zn-La SACs loaded on carbon nitride nanosheets were obtained. HAADF-STEM images showed that Zn and La were uniformly distributed on the single-atom sites (Figs. 3(e) and 3(f)). DFT calculation results showed that the N-doped amorphous carbon substrate caused the bonding orbit near the Fermi level, while the anti-bonding orbit was caused by Zn and amorphous carbon. 2.1.2 Co-precipitation method Co-precipitation is a mature catalyst preparation method. By adding a precipitant into two or more metal salt solutions, the metal precursor is precipitated, and a uniformly dispersed supported catalyst is obtained after treatment. Because of its simple preparation process, SACs are widely prepared via co-precipitation. However, SACs prepared through this method generally have low metal loadings, poor electrocatalytic performance, and are affected by multiple preparation parameters. Zhang and co-workers [38] successfully prepared a Pt/FeO x SAC with a Pt loading of 0.17 wt% and Pt/Fe atomic ratio of 1:1430 via co-precipitation. By analyzing HAADF images and FTIR spectra, it could be confirmed that Pt existed as isolated, positively-charged single atoms on the surface of the carrier and near-surface of the FeO x crystals. In the CO oxidation reaction, the Pt/FeO x SAC showed 2–3 times higher catalytic activity, in terms of the CO oxidation rate and turnover frequency (TOF), and excellent catalytic stability than an Au/Fe2O3 catalyst. Based on DFT, the researchers demonstrated that this was due to the high number of d-orbital vacancies of Pt atoms anchored on the FeO x surface. To improve the applicability of SACs, a Pd SAC with a bimetallic oxide as support (Pd-ZnO-ZrO2) was synthesized via an improved in situ co-precipitation method on a multi-gram scale, which was reported by Zhang et al. [63]. In the synthesis, the Pd precursor of Pd-ZnO-ZrO2 was K2PdCl4. After mixing the aqueous solutions of K2PdCl4 and (NH4)2CO3, a precipitate was formed, which was washed, dried, and calcined at 500 °C to obtain a Pd SAC. The peak at 1.55 Å in the Pd K-edge EXAFS spectrum and the linear combination fitting results of the full X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectrum confirmed Pd in the +2 oxidation state (Fig. 4(a) ), and showed that the Pd in Pd-ZnO-ZrO2 formed a Pd-O2 coordination structure with the O in the macropores of the support. After the carbon-carbon coupling reaction, the catalyst showed wide versatility and reusability in the phosphorus-free Suzuki-Miyaura coupling (SMC) reaction. Furthermore, when compared with Pd-ZnO and Pd-ZrO2, it was revealed that the coordination structure of Pd-O2 enhanced the catalytic performance of Pd-ZnO-ZrO2. Changing the metal loading in catalysts usually affects their surface morphology and catalytic performance. Frei and co-workers [64] reported Ni x Mg1–x O SACs with different Ni loadings (approximately 1 atom%–10 atom%) synthesized via co-precipitation. In the synthesis, the metal precursor solutions of Ni and Mg were added in the medium mole of ammonia, and the precipitate was stirred. The washed precipitate was calcined in synthetic air (with 21% oxygen) to obtain Ni x Mg1–x O SACs. In the catalyst, MgO and NiO with the same lattice parameters formed a solid solution to prevent the Ni atoms from forming clusters (Fig. 4(b)). Characterization of the catalysts showed that Ni2+ replaced the low-coordinated Mg2+ in the support, including surface step sites and angular sites, which changed the metal coordination saturation level of the entire catalyst. This change reduced the adsorption energy barrier of CO2 during the reaction, which improved the catalytic performance. The increase in Ni loading enhanced the adsorption of CO (Fig. 4(c)), and no Ni clusters were found in the Ni x Mg1–x O SAC with a loading of 10 atom% after the reaction. 2.1.3 Precipitation-deposition method As a traditional method for preparing catalysts, precipitation-deposition has also been used to prepare SACs in recent years [65–67]. Researchers have managed to deposit highly dispersed metal atoms on carriers by adjusting the concentration of the metal solution. The disadvantage of this method is that the metal loading is often low in the SACs. Liu et al. [68] reported a Au-based SAC (Au/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2) with a high CO adsorption ability and good catalytic activity, which was prepared via precipitation-deposition. The catalyst displayed excellent catalytic performance in the preferential oxidation of carbon monoxide (CO-PROX), and the synergy between the adjacent single-atom Au and Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 had an influence on the catalytic performance. The catalytic reaction pathway was thought to proceed via the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism (Fig. 4(d)). In the synthesis, researchers first doped Zr4+ into CeO2 via co-precipitation to obtain Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 with excellent thermal mobility as a SAC carrier. Thereafter, in the neutral environment, the precursor HAuCl4 was added into the solution of Ce0.5Zr0.5O2, and the final Au/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 was obtained by stirring, aging, and filtering. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and HAADF-STEM images showed that Au existed as isolated monatomic sites on the support (Figs. 4(e) and 4(f)). XPS analysis revealed that Au existed as isolated single-atom sites in 0.02 wt% Au/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 and 0.05 wt% Au/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2, but as nanoclusters in 0.2 wt% Au/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2. By anchoring metallic Pd on different carbon nitride scaffolds, Sharon and co-workers [69] synthesized Pd SACs (Pd-PHI, Pd-PTI, Pd-GCN, and Pd-LMO) via precipitation-deposition. XPS analysis (Fig. 5(a) ) showed that the Pd2+/Pd4+ ratios in the prepared Pd SACs were different. The researchers proposed that the interaction strength between the metal and carrier in SACs could be controlled by manipulating the skeleton structure of the carbon and nitrogen compounds. 2.1.4 Electrochemical deposition method Electrochemical deposition is a widely used method for synthesizing heterogeneous catalysts. In the preparation process of SACs, the key is to make the metal gain and lose electrons on the surface of the electrode using an external electric field and then deposit the metal on a cathode or anode carrier [70]. Zeng and co-workers [71–73] successfully prepared a variety of SACs via electrochemical deposition and found that the same metal SACs had different electronic states in the cathode and anode and can be used to catalyze the HER and OER on the cathode and anode, respectively. In the Co0.8Fe0.2Se2@Ni foam experiment, Ir single atoms were deposited on Co(OH)2 nanosheets through electrochemical deposition (Figs. 5(b) and 5(c)) [73]. When the Ir SAC was used as a catalyst, the electrochemical test results showed that the alkaline hydrogen evolution current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 8 mV, indicating great potential in the HER. SACs can be optimized by adjusting the deposition conditions or electrolytes in the synthesis. Chen et al. [70] reported a Cu SAC (Cu SACs/SNGF) prepared through an underpotential deposition (UPD) method. The support used was a nitrogen co-doped graphite foam (SNGF) synthesized via a hydrothermal method (Fig. 5(e)). Cu SACs/SNGF was obtained through constant potential deposition, and the Cu loading could be adjusted by changing the potential or the S content in the SNGF. XPS and EXAFS analyses (Fig. 5(d)) showed that a Cu–S bond was formed in the catalyst, and the CuO3S coordination structure existed, both of which improved the ORR activity of Cu SACs/SNGF. Furthermore, the electrochemical deposition method is suitable for synthesizing various metal SACs on different carriers. Wu and co-workers[74] reported the direct synthesis of a Pt SAC (Pt-SAs/C) on graphite carbon paper via electrochemical deposition. During the synthesis process (Fig. 6(a) ), a graphene oxide film (GOM) was added between the counter electrode and working electrode, and the platinum ions released from the bulk platinum foil were screened using the GOM with a multi-layer structure. As shown on the right side of Fig. 6(a), only a small amount of Pt ions reached the working electrode (Fig. 6(b)). This effectively prevented the Pt ions from directly reaching the working electrode, suppressed the concentration of Pt ions near the working electrode, and caused the Pt ions to be reduced in a single atomic state on the electrode. The XANES spectra acquired showed that the oxidation state of Pt in Pt-SAs/C was close to 0 (Fig. 6(c)). The researchers also used this synthesis method to prepare Au-SAs/C, Pt-SAs/pyrolyzed ZIF-8, and other metal SACs, which had isolated and dispersed monatomic sites based on HAADF-STEM analysis. 2.1.5 Atomic-layer deposition method The atomic-layer deposition method, which was first reported by Suntola [75], is a catalyst synthesis method that can accurately control the structure of catalytically active sites. The catalyst synthesis can be accurately controlled on a support by controlling the number of deposition cycles and changing the cycle type during preparation. The self-restriction of this method can effectively prevent metal aggregation, but there exists some complex problems, such as the appearance of structures that are inconsistent with those expected due to the surface segregation of atoms, long preparation process, and high cost of the experiment [76]. Lu and co-workers [77] prepared Pd1/graphene SACs via atomic-layer deposition using functionalized graphene as a SAC carrier. In the preparation process (Fig. 6(d)), the type and amount of graphene groups that reacted with the Pd(hfac)2 precursor on the support were finely controlled to anchor Pt single atoms while removing the hexafluoroacetylacetate (hfac) ligands. HAADF-STEM images showed that there was no Pd cluster on Pd1/graphene, and each Pd atom was randomly distributed on the carrier. The Pd1/graphene SAC showed excellent durability in the selective hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene after 100 h, which included 50-h propylene-free and 50-h propylene-abundant periods (Fig. 6(e)). Using nitrogen-doped graphene nanosheets as a support, Cheng et al. [50] prepared Pt SACs and Pt cluster catalysts through atomic-layer deposition. The atomic-layer deposition cycle could be designed for each precursor MeCpPtMe3 pulse 1 s, O2 pulse 5 s, and N2 purge separation of 20 s. Comparing the morphology of ALD Pt/NGN obtained using different cycles, it was found that the size of Pt in the catalyst could be controlled by changing the number of deposition cycles. After the HER electrocatalytic experiments, the catalytic activity of ALD50Pt/NGN was approximately eight times that of ALD100Pt/NGN. Pt single-atom active sites were crucial for improving catalytic activity (Fig. 6(f)). Precise control of the atomic layer deposition process has great potential in controlling the synthesis of bimetallic SACs and reducing the cost of precious-metal catalysts. Sun and co-workers [76] reported a two-step atomic-layer deposition method for the synthesis of bimetallic PtRu SACs (Pt-Ru dimers) on nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs), where the existence of a Pt–Ru bond resulted in the highest total unoccupied density of states of the Pt 5d character of 1.09, which was significantly beneficial to the HER performance. In the synthesis (Fig. 7(a) ), the Pt precursors were first adsorbed and then reduced to Pt atoms, which were uniformly dispersed around the N atoms in the carrier. The comparison of the EXAFS spectra and normalized XANES spectra revealed the formation of Pt–N/Pt–C and Ru–C bonds in the PtRu SACs, excluding the formation of coordination structures of Pt and O in the carrier (Figs. 7(b) and 7(c)). Thereafter, Ru was selectively deposited on Pt at 270 °C to obtain Pt-Ru dimers with a Pt–Ru bonding distance of 0.24 ± 0.04 nm. In the HER, the Pt-Ru dimers with 0.9 wt% Pt loading exhibited high activity and good stability. The self-restraint of the ALD method can control the preparation of SACs and prevent the agglomeration of metallic single atoms. Typically, during the preparation process, owing to the high dissociation energy barrier of the metal precursor on the surface of the carbon-based carrier, high metal-loaded SACs are difficult to obtain, but when the metal surface is loaded, the dissociation energy of the metal precursor decreases. Li et al. [78] considered loading the precursor Co(Cp)2 on N-doped carbon nanosheets (NCNS) with uniformly dispersed Pt single atoms, so that the precursor was fully dissociated to form a highly Co-loaded SAC (Co1Pt1/NCNS). During the preparation of the Co-based SAC, the researchers first explored N-doped carbon nanosheets as a carrier. When compared with Pt, which can be uniformly dispersed on the carrier up to a Pt loading of 2.0 wt%, a Co loading of 0.5 wt%, produced nanoclusters on the NCNS. The high dissociation energy (ΔG de = 4.91 eV) of Co(Cp)2 on the NCNS surface resulted in weak physical adsorption and the easy agglomeration of Co atoms. The presence of Pt effectively reduced the dissociation energy between Co and Cp (ΔG de = 3.54 eV), and the adsorption of Co(Cp)2 on the Pt1 atom (ΔG ad = +0.06 eV) was easier than that observed on the NCNS surface (ΔG ad = –0.32 eV) (Fig. 8(f) ). After implementing improvements, a new Co ALD cycle was conducted on the basis of Pt1/NCNS to obtain Co1Pt1/NCNS (Fig. 8(a)). When compared with Co-NPs/NCNS, the Co1Pt1/NCNS exhibited better catalytic performances in the HER and OER. In the HAADF-STEM image, Co1Pt1/NCNS showed uniformly dispersed Pt and Co single atoms (Fig. 8(b)). The appearance of Co L2 and L3 during electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) further proved the existence of Co in the form of single atoms. In the XANES analysis, the structure of 2O2 Co1-pyrrolic N4, which was obtained by adding two dioxygen molecules to the Co1 atom, conformed to the theoretical structure (Fig. 8(e)). Moreover, the single atom properties and electronic properties of Pt in Co1Pt1/NCNS remained unchanged, indicating that Pt played a role similar to that of the catalyst in the synthesis. The researchers also explored the applicability of the improved ALD method to prepare Fe-based (Fe1Pt1/NCNS) and Ni-based (Ni1Pt1/NCNS) SACs, and their experimental results were similar to those of Co1Pt1/NCNS (Figs. 8(c) and 8(d)) [78]. This showed that Pt can effectively promote the dissociation of metal precursors on the surface of the Pt-containing support, making this improved method highly applicable. 2.1.6 Defect design method In defect design synthesis, the coordination between the electronic structure of the carrier and the surrounding structure can be adjusted by controlling the defect structure, thereby forming an unsaturated coordination environment and vacancies. These defects can be used as single-atom traps and stable anchor points. Guo et al. [79] synthesized PtSA-CN via the in situ photocatalytic reduction of g-C3N4 with a large number of N vacancies to strengthen the reactive metal-support interaction between Pt single atoms and g-C3N4. The higher the number of N vacancies, the more pronounced the metal-support interaction (RMSI) became (Fig. 9(a) ). In the synthesis, g-C3N4, with different N vacancy contents synthesized at different temperatures in a N2 atmosphere, was mixed with the aqueous Pt precursor solution, and then subjected to liquid-nitrogen freezing and Xe lamp irradiation. The synthesis method was conducive to the adsorption of Pt single atoms by the two-coordinated C (C2C) on the surface of g-C3N4. The high defect environment has an influence on the reaction path of the catalyst. In previous reports, the number of Ni-N coordination sites often affected the adsorption strength of different intermediates in the CO2RR, and the rate-determining step also varied. Zhao and co-workers [80] reported a vacancy design strategy to synthesize Ni SACs with a stable unsaturated Ni-pyridinic Ni-N2 coordination structure with N vacancies (SA-NiNG-NV) (Figs. 9(b) and 9(c)). In the experiment, microwave-induced plasma treatment enabled the uniform adsorption of Ni and N on graphene oxide to form a Ni-N-C configuration. The longer the treatment time, the more N vacancies appeared in SA-NiNG-NV. The unsaturated coordination structure of Ni-N2 had a long Ni–N bond, and the defective graphene plane formed during the adsorption of CO2 made the active Ni site easier to bind to CO2, so that the catalyst exhibits excellent CO2RR performance. However, the structure displayed poor HER activity, which decreased the competitiveness of the HER. As a catalyst support, the defective tubular support material can provide more anchor points on the surface to anchor active metal atoms. The coordination structure formed by such supports and metal precursors (and their special geometric spatial structure) can improve the uniformity and dispersion of single atoms to maximize the stability and performance of catalysts. Zhang and co-workers [81] reported that the morphology and defects of the catalyst support material (g-C3N4) were designed to form a hollow tube structure with an abundance of N vacancies (NV-TCN), and Mo SACs were obtained by anchoring Mo on the surface of NV-TCN with different Mo loadings (Mo/NV-TCN) (Fig. 9(d)). The N vacancies formed by the specific lattices in the catalyst were produced via the annealing of TCN in a N2 atmosphere. Combined with EXAFS and DFT analyses (Fig. 9(e)), the stability of the Mo-2C/2N coordination structure of the catalyst (–6.68 eV adsorption energy) was conducive to the photoexcited charge transfer of the catalyst, in which Mo was the main active site for photocatalysis. 2.1.7 Spatial confinement method The spatial confinement strategy is a method used to limit the metal atoms in the pore structure of porous materials to hinder the aggregation of atoms and make them uniformly dispersed. Porous materials, such as zeolites and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), are generally used as carriers. Wang and co-workers [82] synthesized a highly stable Fe SAC (Fe ISAs/CN) by anchoring Fe atoms on ZIF-8 via the spatial confinement method. The ZIF-8 cavity diameter was 11.6 Å and the pore size was 3.4 Å. During the synthesis (Fig. 10(a) ), the SAC precursor Fe(acac)3 was mixed with ZIF-8 to form a cage structure, which was then pyrolyzed at 900 °C in a Ar atmosphere. The HAADF-STEM image acquired (Figs. 10(b) and 10(c)) showed that Fe existed as isolated monatomic Fe in the catalyst. The Fe loading in Fe ISAs/CN (based on inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry) was 2.16 wt%. The interlayer sub-nanospace was also designed to limit metal atoms during the synthesis of high-metal-loading SACs. Quan et al. [83] prepared Pt SACs with Pt loadings of up to 8.7 wt%. The researchers exchanged Pt atoms for K+ ions intercalated in the potassium ions of carbon nitride via the electrostatic induction ion exchange method (Figs. 10(d) and 10(e)), so that they were limited to the sub-nano level interlayer of the catalyst. The XPS and EXAFS analysis results showed that the coordination structure of Pt and N in the catalyst was a planar square configuration, and under the constraint of sub-nanometer layers, Pt maintained a good monatomic dispersion at high loadings. Fe-based catalysts with uniformly dispersed single Fe atoms and target coordination structures were usually difficult to obtain using direct high-temperature synthesis methods. Using the space limitation ability of Ce and its surface trapping metal sites, Lin and co-workers [84] designed a method to prevent Fe agglomeration during heat treatment and prepared a 4.6 wt% Fe SAC (Ce/Fe-NCNW). The synthesis conditions and Fe:Ce ratio have an influence on the catalyst performance. At 900 °C, Ce/Fe-NCNW with a Fe:Ce ratio of 1:1 exhibited the highest ORR performance (Fig. 10(f)). Using EXAFS curves and fitting structural parameters, the researchers analyzed and proposed the coordination relationship between one oxygen in CeO2 and one Fe atom perpendicular to the Fe-N4 plane. Ce in the carrier mainly existed in the form of Ce3+ and Ce4+, and the Ce3+/Ce4+ redox couple led to a charge imbalance, which promoted the ORR [85]. 2.2 Top-down synthesis strategies SACs produced through these new synthesis strategies often have the advantages of high loadings, high sample yields, and accurately-controlled coordination structure. Generally, the synthesis environment, including gas atmosphere concentration and heat treatment temperature, needs to be controlled more accurately. 2.2.1 High-temperature atom-capture method In the high-temperature atom-transfer-capture method, the metal precursor is transformed into a gas at high temperature, and then the metal atoms migrate to the surface defect positions of the carrier to form a strong interaction between the metal atoms and carrier, resulting in the formation of a stable and well-dispersed metal SACs with high loading. Zhang et al. [86] prepared a thermally stable Pt SAC via the high-temperature atom-transfer-capture method using isolated Pt atoms with strong covalent metal-support interactions (CMSI) with the Fe and O atoms on the support surface. In the experiment, 0.3 wt% Fe2O3 was loaded on the colloidal Pt nanoparticles (NPs), and the ethylene glycol stabilizer was removed via calcination at 500 °C. After calcination at 800 °C for 5 h, a very high density of isolated Pt atoms was generated, thereby forming a Pt SAC. DFT studies showed that iron oxide reduction was the key to anchoring isolated Pt atoms. The reverse sintering effect (or atomization effect) at high temperatures (approximately 900–1000 °C) can transform nanoparticles into isolated single atoms. Li and co-workers [87] prepared SACs of precious metals (such as Pd, Pt, and Au) by employing the high-temperature atom-migration-capture method. In the experiment (Fig. 11(a) ), nitrogen-doped carbon was selected as the anchoring substrate, and Pd-NPs@ZIF-8 composites were heated at 900 °C for 3 h in a nitrogen atmosphere in tubular furnace, and then cooled to obtain Pd SACs, and accordingly, Pt SACs as well as Au SACs were successfully fabricated by changing the calcination temperature to 1000 °C and the time to 5 h. Using HAADF-STEM, it was confirmed that there were single noble metal atoms uniformly distributed on the nitrogen-doped carbon carrier. EXAFS spectra revealed that the metallic bonds in SACs were transformed into M–N bonds, which existed between the metal and carrier and confirmed the successful synthesis of noble metal SACs. The coordination environment of metals in SACs has a great influence on catalytic performance. Cao et al. [88] reported that metallic nanoparticles were converted to metal (Fe, Co, Ni, and Mn) SACs with high metal loadings (> 10 wt%) at an isolated point via high-temperature migration and capture. In the synthesis of Fe SACs, Fe3O4/rGO was encapsulated by highly cross-linked poly, and then pyrolyzed at 750 °C in an Ar atmosphere to obtain SA Fe/C, where the Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio was approximately 1:1 (Fig. 11(b)). At different calcination temperatures, in situ TEM images showed that cyclotriphosphazene-co-4,4′-sulfonyldiphenol (PZS) facilitated the transformation of Fe nanoparticles to monatomic Fe. DFT calculations also showed that the isolated Fe atoms formed stable Fe1-O4-P4 structures in graphene at approximately 750 °C. 2.2.2 In situ pyrolysis method In situ pyrolysis is a preparation method that can be used to synthesize SACs with high surface density. Generally, materials with high surface areas and a high number of in situ-generated rich binding sites are used as supports, such as porous heteroatom-doped carbon, covalent trinitrogen frameworks, and carbon nitrides. Zhu and co-workers [89] prepared a Ni SAC with high CO2 reduction performances via in situ pyrolysis. In the experiment, a metal precursor with fluoride ions was mixed with PTFE, cooled and dried, and then pyrolyzed at 900 °C in Ar to prepare a Ni SAC. The characterization results acquired showed that the Ni content in the catalyst was 5.92 atom%, and that the SAC exhibited excellent CO2RR performance in the potential range of approximately –0.67––0.97 V, that is, a Faraday efficiency for CO production of 95%. The DFT simulation results revealed that doping F into the Ni SAC enhanced the adsorption of the intermediate *COOH on the active sites of the catalyst during CO2RR. The effect of M-N-C on the synthesis of non-noble metal SACs is being increasingly studied. Sun and co-workers [90] reported a type of Fe SAC (Fe-N x -C) with an Fe-Phen complex synthesized on the nitrogen-doped carbon framework via in situ pyrolysis (Figs. 11(c) and 11(d)). The prepared Fe SACs showed high catalytic performance in the ORR and excellent performance in zinc-air batteries (ZABs). X-ray diffraction (XRD), EELS, and other characterization techniques showed that the monatomic Fe catalyst had a zeolite-like structure and the coordination form of Fe-N x existed. In their subsequent explorations, the researchers found that this synthesis procedure could also be used to synthesize non-noble metal SACs, such as those based on Co and Ni. To solve the problem that high-temperature pyrolysis affects the precise control of active sites, Zhu et al. [91] reported a self-sacrificed templating approach to prepare Fe SACs on a graphene support (Fe/N-G-SAC) with high ORR and OER electrocatalytic properties via in situ pyrolysis (Fig. 11(e)). The excessive Fe clusters in the metal precursor not only promoted the formation of Fe-N4 edge active sites, but also formed a large number of mesoporous structures on the support, which were conducive to electrochemical transfer. The researchers performed DFT calculations to simulate the feasibility of the synthesis procedure. During the synthesis, 1,8-diaminonaphthalene/FeCl3 with a ratio of 1:10 was pyrolyzed to form a precursor in N2, and then the unstable Fe species were removed via acid hydrolysis to obtain the Fe/N-G-SAC. The lower OH* adsorption free energy of the Fe-N4 edge sites confirmed that the Fe-N4 edge sites were more advantageous for the ORR than the Fe-N4 planar sites (Fig. 11(f)). 2.2.3 Flame-spray pyrolysis method As a commonly used method for preparing functional and complex nanoparticle catalysts, flame-spray pyrolysis has been developed and used to prepare SACs [92]. Yan et al. [93] synthesized Pt SACs on different carriers (Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, and ZrO) using the flame-spray pyrolysis strategy. By comparison, it was found that Pt SACs had the best stability when ZrO2 was used as the carrier. A 0.2 Pt/ZrO2 SAC displayed the highest Pt atom dispersion ratio and the ZrO2 carrier exhibited a tetragonal-monoclinic mixture. In the study of the 0.2 Pt/ZrO2 catalyst, flame-spray pyrolysis was conducive to the formation of the tetragonal-monoclinic ZrO2 mixture. The support with this structure could improve the oxygen reduction performance of the catalyst, thereby also improving the performance of the catalyst in high-temperature reactions, such as CO oxidation, as well as partial and total CH4 combustion. The total concentration of Pt and the precursor of each carrier, and the flow rate of methane and oxygen could be controlled through these two parameters to alter the coordination structure of Pt-O, so as to optimize catalytic performance. The methane/O2 flame method has been used to produce a Pd SA/TiO2 photocatalyst. The group of Pratsinis [54] dispersed the mixed solution of palladium acetylacetonate into a fine spray and ignited it. The characterization results obtained showed that the content of Pd in the catalyst was approximately 0.025 wt%–0.1 wt%. Pd SA/TiO2 showed excellent solar-light photocatalytic NO x removal when the proportion of Pd on the TiO2 surface was approximately 40%–70%. Hensen et al. [94] prepared Pd/CeO2 SACs via two methods, namely, conventional impregnation and one-step flame-spray pyrolysis. The Pd/CeO2 SAC prepared via flame-spray pyrolysis exhibited good Pd isolation, high structural stability, a large surface area, good high-temperature CO oxidation activity, and high resistance against sintering (Fig. 12(a) ). However, the Pd catalyst prepared via impregnation was easily reduced and agglomerated. Pd2+ ions in the Pd/CeO2 SAC prepared using the FSP method entered the Ce lattice of the support, forming a Pd-O-Ce coordination structure. This helped to enhance the stability of the FSP-derived Pd/CeO2 SAC. 2.3 Other synthesis strategies In recent years, many novel and excellent strategies have been designed and developed for the rapid development of SACs. Controlling the coordination environment of catalysts is of great significance during catalyst synthesis. Wang and co-workers [95] reported the synthesis of Cu SACs on N-doped carbon (Cu SAs/NC) by controlling the coordination environment of Cu via an ionic substitution strategy. During the preparation of the catalyst, a ZIF-8 hexane solution and Cu precursor solution were mixed using ultrasound at room temperature. After 6 h of stirring, the Cu SAs/NC catalyst was dried, ground, and calcined at different temperatures. The Cu SAs/NC-900 catalyst (i.e., calcined at 900 °C), with unsaturated groups (Fig. 12(b)), displayed the highest ORR performance. The structural characterization results obtained showed that there were Cu-N structures in Cu SAs/NC-800 and Cu SAs/NC-900 in the form of CuN4 and CuN3, respectively (Figs. 12(c) and 12(d)). The excellent uniform structure of the AuPd alloy provides a new idea for the synthesis of efficient SACs. Zhang et al. [96] used the ion exchange-NaBH4 reduction method to synthesize PdAu SACs using an ion exchange resin as a support (Au6Pd/resin), and the total metal loading was 2.0 wt%. Based on the XAFS and DFT calculation results obtained at different Au:Pd ratios, it was inferred that when the Au:Pd ratio was greater than 4, Au gradually segregated from Pd, and when the ratio was greater than 10, the Au-alloyed Pd single-atom structure appeared in Au6Pd/resin. Photochemical reduction can also be used to synthesize metal nanocrystals, where metal atoms are transformed into nanocrystals through a nucleation process. However, in recent years, Wei et al. [97] found that temperature, which is one of the most important factors in liquid-phase reactions, could effectively inhibit the reaction process and determine the reaction rate. In the investigation of ultra-low temperature photochemical reactions, they successfully synthesized isolated Pt SACs (Pt SACs). In the synthesis, the researchers placed an antifreeze solution of the metal precursor H2PtCl6 at –60 °C and reduced it with ultraviolet light to form atomically dispersed Pt atoms, and then mixed the solution with N-doped mesoporous carbon (NMC) to obtain Pt SACs/NMC. The HAADF-STEM image obtained showed that Pt was atomically well-dispersed on the carrier and did not agglomerate into nanoparticles or atomic clusters. Ab-initio Molecular Dynamics (AIMD) simulation showed that the negative correlation between low temperature and ethanol volume temperature was key for achieving atomic dispersion. 3 DFT calculations and principles of different electrochemical energy conversion reactions The development of efficient, green, and sustainable electrocatalytic reaction systems, including HER, OER, ORR, CO2RR, and NRR, is imperative in response to the needs of natural environment protection and the soaring energy consumption. DFT based on simulated catalyst structures and the changes in the Gibbs free energy can theoretically calculate electronic structures of different catalytic system. It is the most powerful theoretical calculation method for establishing relationships between catalyst structure and activity in electrocatalytic reactions at the atomic level. This can effectively solve the problems related to the detection of intermediate states, active sites, and free energy conversion during the short and rapid electron transfer processes in electrocatalytic systems [98]. Moreover, the combination of DFT calculations and experimental results can accelerate our understanding of catalytic mechanisms and provide theoretical support for the prediction and screening of catalytically active materials [99,100]. It is well known that the Sabatier principle reveals the interaction between adsorbing catalyst surfaces and adsorbates [101–103]. For example, weak binding makes the catalytic reaction difficult to activate/initiate, while strong adsorption inhibits the conversion of reaction intermediates to products or the desorption of products. There is a “volcano-like” relationship between adsorption energy and catalytic activity, where the highest activity sits at the tip of the volcano, and the adsorption energy of the catalyst is not too strong or too weak. The adsorption energy (ΔE ads) is calculated as follows [104]: (1) ΔE ads = E cat/adsorbate − E cat − E adsorbate E cat is the catalyst energy, E adsorbate is the energy of the isolated adsorbate, and ΔE cat/adsorbate is the total energy of the substance produced during the reaction of the catalyst and adsorbate. With the development of electrochemical energy conversion, Nørskov and colleagues proposed the famous electrochemical thermodynamic framework (ETF) [105,106]. This framework quantifies the Sabatier principle and solves problems such as the binding energy at the peak of the volcano. In the “volcano” diagram under this framework, due to the discovery of the scaling relationship, there is a linear relationship between various adsorbates on the horizontal axis, that is, the adsorption energy of one of the adsorbates can be obtained, and the remaining adsorption energy can also be obtained through this linear relationship. In the longitudinal axis, the maximum standard Gibbs free energy differences (ΔG 0 max) of all steps is observed with the rate-limiting step of the reaction, then the calculation formula of TOF is as follows [104]: (2) TOF = −ΔG 0 max/RT Thus, with the support of theoretical calculations, the “volcano” diagrams of various electrocatalytic reactions can be calculated and the catalysts with the best catalytic performance are predicted. 3.1 ORR and OER As the cathode half reaction of the battery, the slow reaction rate and multi-step reaction steps of the ORR greatly limit the industrial development of clean energy systems such as polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFCs), proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), and anion exchange membrane fuel cells (AEMFCs). Typically, the ORR is a proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) process involving four electron transfers to reduce O2 to H2O. Due to the complexity of the reaction, different reaction pathways are involved, which include intermediates such as oxygen (*O), hydroxyl (*OH), and super hydroxyl (*OOH). The followings are the reactions of the dissociative and associative steps [105]: Dissociative steps: (3) O2 + 2* → 2*O (4) 2*O + 2H+ + 2e− → 2*OH (5) 2*OH + 2H+ + 2e− → 2H2O + 2* Associative steps: (6) O2 + * → *O2 (7) *O2 + H+ + e− → *OOH (8) *OOH + H+ + e− → *O + H2O (9) *O + H+ + e− → *OH (10) *OH + H+ + e− → H2O + * During the reaction, the adsorption energies of all involved intermediates on the catalyst surface play a key role in determining catalytic performance. In the volcano plot of catalytic activity prepared using the scaling relationship, the rising portion on the left represents the strongly bound portion where the ORR over metal-based catalysts is limited by the formation of *O or *OH; the right side represents weak binding, and the breaking of *O2 and O–O becomes the rate-determining step of the reaction. Among the metals, Pt, which is closest to the volcanic peak, has a suitable binding energy for oxygen and becomes the best catalyst for the ORR (Fig. 13(a) ). In addition to the limitations of slow kinetics and multi-step reactions, the ORR also has a competitive reaction, which is the production of H2O2 [107]. Using DFT and experimental investigations, it was found that the competitive H2O2 formation reaction via double-electron transfer was more likely to occur on metal-based catalysts that bind oxygen weakly at high potentials [105,107,108]. As a reverse reaction of the ORR, the OER undergoes a four-electron transfer during the electrocatalytic process, breaking down H2O to produce O2, and the intermediates involved in the reaction are also consistent with those of the ORR, namely, *O, *OH and *OOH [109]. In general, the classical reaction mechanism of the OER is considered to be the ate evolution mechanism (AEM) (Fig. 13(b)) [110]. The reaction pathway under alkaline conditions is as follows [110–114]: (11) 4OH− → *OH + 3OH− + e− (12) *OH + 3OH− + e− → *O + H2O + 2OH− + 2e− (13) *O + *O → O2 or (14) *O + H2O + OH− → *OOH + H2O + OH− + 3e− (15) *OOH + OH− + H2O + 3e− → O2 + H2O + 4e− After the intermediate *OH enters the PCET process and generates *O, it may be directly coupled by two *O to form O2; it may also be possible to first combine *O with OH− to obtain the intermediate *OOH, and then *OOH undergoes the PCET process to obtain O2. In the study of the OER activity of electrocatalysts, ΔG *O − ΔG *OH is considered to be the standard for evaluating the best catalyst. Therefore, a catalyst with a binding energy close to 1.6 eV is suitable for OER. Furthermore, just as Pt is the best catalyst for HER and hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) under acidic conditions, it is also considered to be the best ORR and OER catalyst [115]. However, at high positive potentials, the surfaces of pure metal-based catalysts, including Pt-based catalysts, are significantly oxidized, resulting in catalyst deactivation [115]. IrO2 under acidic conditions has a suitable binding energy with intermediates and is one of the best catalysts under such conditions, but it still has a certain gap with the overall ideal catalyst. The high overpotential of the OER is above 1.6 eV and the slow kinetics caused by the multi-step reactions under acidic or alkaline conditions are the main factors limiting the development of the OER [116]. Therefore, the reaction mechanism of the OER needs to be studied further. In recent years, the lattice-oxygen-mediated mechanism (LOM) (Fig. 13(c)) has been proposed and further developed [117,118]. This mechanism indicates that the high metal-oxygen covalency, i.e., the weak binding energy of the metal sites, is conducive to the occurrence of the LOM mechanism, and the regulation of the electronic structure can also control the OER based on the LOM mechanism [119]. 3.2 HER As a very promising sustainable green hydrogen production technology, HER has received significant research attention. In comparison, HER is not a very complex electrocatalytic reaction. The two-electron transfer process of the HER involves only one intermediate, namely, H* [104]. However, its reaction pathway in acidic media has two possibilities, including the Volmer-Heyrovsky or Volmer-Tafel mechanisms (Fig. 13(d)) [120–122]. The reaction steps are as follows [123]: Volmer step: (16) H+ + e− + * → H* Heyrovsky step: (17) H* + H+ + e− → H2 + * Or Tafel step: (18) 2H* → H2 + 2* In the initial Volmer step, H+ adsorbs on the catalyst surface to form the intermediate H*. Thereafter, the Heyrovsky step or Tafel recombination step occurs. The Heyrovsky step combines the intermediate H* with H+ and undergoes an electron transfer to obtain and desorb H2 from the catalyst surface. The Volmer-Tafel pathway occurs after the Volmer step, an H* is coupled with the adjacent H*, resulting in H2 formation. The hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔG H) of the entire reaction determines the reaction rate. The weak binding energy of the catalyst surface to hydrogen (ΔG H > 0) can cause the rate of the Volmer step to limit the rate of the entire reaction. Similarly, very strong binding (ΔG H < 0) can make it difficult for the Heyrovsky or Tafel steps to proceed rapidly, thus limiting the HER kinetics. Therefore, the Volmer step as well as the Heyrovsky or Tafel steps determine the HER activity and ΔG H, with the optimal ΔG H value being close to 0. Pt-based catalysts have been considered to be the best HER catalysts because of their ΔG H value that is close to 0 [124]. Meanwhile, the MoS2 crystal is not favored because the ΔG H of the basal plane is much larger than 0 (1.92 eV). However, in recent years, the ΔG H value of the MoS2 crystal edge calculated using DFT is 0.08 eV, making MoS2 the best non-metallic HER catalyst and the most promising substitute for the rare and expensive Pt-based catalysts (Fig. 13(e)) [125]. 3.3 CO2RR Carbon dioxide reduction to fuels and other valuable chemicals is a promising way of decreasing global CO2 levels, and has been vigorously developed in recent years [126]. Through the complex CO2RR pathway, CO2 can selectively produce various products, such as C1 (including CO, CH4, CH3OH, HCOOH, etc.), C2 (C2H4, C2H5OH, etc.), and C3 hydrocarbons (C3H7OH, etc.) [127–129]. The diversity of products further reflects the complexity of the CO2RR. In the CO2 reduction pathway, the multi-step PCET produces different intermediates, such as CO, which is obtained via a two-electron transfer, as well as C2H4 and C2H5OH, which are formed via a six-electron transfer (Fig. 14(a) ) [104,130]. The CO-formation pathway is as follows [131]: (19) CO2 + * + H+ + e− → *COOH (20) *COOH + H+ + e− → *CO + H2O (21) *CO → CO + * Generally, since the scaling relationship exists for the intermediate of CO2RR, the adsorption energy of the key intermediate determines catalytic activity, but it is also the decisive factor for catalytic selectivity in the CO2RR [132]. The intermediate *COOH, with strong adsorption, is easily combined with transition metals to form CO, while metals, such as Sn and Pb, selectively adsorb the intermediate *OCHO and subsequently produce HCOOH. The reaction pathway and product selectivity of deep reduction products, such as C2 and C3 hydrocarbons, are determined by the binding energy of *CO and the following intermediate obtained via reduction. For example, in the conversion process of C2H4 and C2H5OH (Fig. 14(b)), the intermediate *H2C2OH can be obtained via PCET, but in the subsequent reaction, the combination of *H and one of the C atoms on *H2C2OH will form two different products, namely, C2H4 or C2H5OH [133]. 3.4 NRR Nitrogen fixation, a reaction that converts N2 into NH= or other soil-related nitrides, can effectively meet the needs of modern agriculture. Different from the Haber-Bosch nitrogen reduction process, which requires high energy and emits high levels of CO2, the NRR is a potential green nitrogen fixation reaction that can reduce energy consumption and CO2 emissions [134]. Electrochemical NRR is a simple six-electron transfer reaction for producing NH3 via PCET; one of the NH3 production pathways is as follows [110]: (22) N2 + 6H+ + 6e− → 2NH3 The mechanisms by which NRR take place are divided into the dissociative and associative pathways (Fig. 14(c)) [135–137]. The dissociative pathway, in the context of electrocatalysis, the nitrogen-nitrogen triple bond is first broken, and the two resulting N atoms are adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst. Thereafter, the PCET process occurs, and the N atoms are hydrogenated to NH3. There are two possible cases in the associative pathway, including the associative distal pathway and associative alternating pathway, but in both cases, N2 molecules bind to the catalyst surface first. It is important to note that the N atoms in the associative distal pathway are far away from the catalyst surface, that is, there is no direct contact with the catalyst surface. The hydrogenation reaction occurs to form NH3 and leaves the metal-nitrogen triple bond, and then the remaining N is hydrogenated to form NH3. In the associative alternating pathway, the two N atoms of the N2 molecule are alternately hydrogenated, and almost simultaneously generate NH3 and get desorbed [135]. Furthermore, there may be side reactions involving a four-electron transfer to form N2H4 and two-electron transfer to form N2H2 during NRR. The reaction pathways to each side product are as follows [110]: N2H4 pathway: Acidity: (23) N2 + 5H+ + 4e− → N2H5 + Alkalinity: (24) N2 + 4H2O + 4e− → N2H4 + 4OH− N2H2 pathway: (25) N2 + 2H+ + 2e− → N2H2 A theoretical overpotential and ΔG N volcanic diagram was constructed based on DFT calculation results to screen the best NRR catalyst [121,134,138]. Metal-based catalysts with weak nitrogen binding were limited in the conversion of *N2 to intermediate *N2H; very strong binding made the conversion of *NH to *NH2 or *NH2 to NH3 difficult (Fig. 14(d)) [139–141]. Among the many metals considered, Ru, Mo, and Fe are excellent NRR catalysts because of their suitable binding strength with nitrogen, but their overpotential is above 0.5 eV (Fig. 14(e)) [138]. In the field of electrochemical energy conversion, the type of metal center atoms in the active sites of SACs is not the only way to optimize catalytic activity [239,240]. SACs with the same metal base may have different reaction results in the same reaction, and may also show impressive catalytic performances in different fields [226]. The difference between these SACs is sometimes only the compositional increase or decrease of a non-metallic atom around the central metal atom of the active site, which in turn changes the electronic valence state of the central metal atom, bonding properties of the surrounding atoms, and overall coordination structure [241]. These are enough to make significant changes in catalytic performance. The SACs with coordination environments of Fe-N3 and Fe-N4 have shown great differences in catalytic performance in the synthesis of nitriles, and Fe-N4 at room temperature has almost no effect [242]. Interestingly, Fe-N-C, which also has a Fe-N x coordination structure, showed nearly twice the performance of FeN3 in the ORR [243]. These differences mean that the coordination environments of the active centers of SACs are relatively easy to clarify and have a significant impact on the catalytic reaction. From the perspective of DFT, electrochemical energy conversion reactions need to cross their energy barriers in one reaction step after another with the help of SACs, that is, the energy required for the generation, combination, and desorption of a series of substances from raw materials to products. Different coordination environments, including nitrogen coordination, nitrogen-carbon coordination, sulfur coordination, and metal coordination, in SACs play different roles in the many reaction steps and their optimization is a continuous research task [244,245]. M-N4 is generally considered the best CO2RR coordination structure [246]. Many Ni- and Fe-based SACs with this kind of coordination structure also show excellent performance in the CO2RR. It is important to mention that Ni and Fe were initially considered excellent HER catalysts, which is a competitive reaction of CO2RR. However, in recent years, many studies have found that SACs with coordination structures, such as M-N3, M-N3-C, and M-N2-V2, show better performance than those with M-N4 in the CO2RR to selectively form CO. This is mainly due to the more suitable binding energy of the *COOH intermediate. On the contrary, as previously mentioned, FeN4 (in Fe-N-C) with a better ORR performance, allows O to be adsorbed at a more favorable position and forms a moderately strong Fe–O bond, which in turn facilitates the adsorption of intermediates *OH and *OOH, while avoiding the deactivation of the active site. Similarly, in the HER, OER, and NRR, the effect of the same coordination environment may be very different [247]. In electrochemical energy conversion, the optimal coordination environment is not determined by the type of active metal and type of reaction. By defining the reaction type, selecting the target product, determining the reaction pathway, and then optimizing and comparing the effective structure through DFT calculations, SACs with the most favorable coordination environment for the reaction can be found [248]. 4 Applications of metal SACs in different electrocatalytic reactions Based on the characteristics of maximum source utilization and unique electronic structure, SACs have shown excellent electrocatalytic activity and long-term stability in various electrocatalytic reactions. This is of great significance for the development of efficient electrocatalysts [17,44,97]. Here, the applications of metal SACs in different electrocatalytic reactions, such as the OER, HER, ORR, CO2RR, and NRR, reported in recent years are reviewed. 4.1 Application of metal SACs in the OER The OER plays an indispensable role in various electrochemical applications, such as fuel cells and optoelectronic chemical batteries. As one of the electrochemical water splitting reactions, the OER exhibits slow kinetics, thereby delaying the electrochemical production rate of H2. As shown in Table 1 , many efficient SACs applied in the OER have received great research attention in recent years [71,129,142–154]. At the same time, it is necessary to continue to develop SACs in an attempt to maximize the OER activity. It is generally believed that Ir- and Ru-based catalysts perform best in the OER [155–157]. Gu and co-workers [158] synthesized CoO x ANSs doped with Ir single atoms (SAs). The main reasons for the formation of Ir SAs in the catalyst were the surface adsorption of oxygen and surfactant. Ir SAs-Co13.3O20.1 in the synthesized sample exhibited the best OER performance. SEM and double Cs-corrected STEM analyses showed that Ir SAs-Co13.3O20.1 had an ultra-thin layered structure with a thickness of approximately 1 nm and surface area of 213.3 m2 g−1. The prepared Ir SAs-Co13.3O20.1 was amorphous. In the OER electrochemical test, Ir SAs-Co13.3O20.1 displayed a low Tafel slope (of approximately 60.5 mV dec−1) and high activity, which was 160 times higher than that of commercial IrO2. In exploring the high OER activity of the catalyst, the researchers compared the activity and ESCA and found that the ultrathin amorphous CoO x ANSs loading was beneficial for improving the intrinsic catalytic activity of Ir. XPS results showed that the synergy between Ir and Co and the careful control of the Ir loading could promote the OER activity. After a 10-h durability test at 1.38 V vs. the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), the current density of Ir SAs-Co13.3O20.1 remained stable, while that of IrO2 decreased by 72%. Ex situ STEM showed that Ir SAs-Co13.3O20.1 had high structural stability. The good isolation and uniformity of Ir atoms on the support surface resulted in excellent catalytic stability. Ir SACs perform well under alkaline or neutral conditions, but are difficult to stabilize under acidic conditions. Cai et al. [159] designed and synthesized a double-protection method for the preparation of Ir SACs (Fig. 15(a) ). Firstly, Ir atoms with poor electrocatalytic stability were dispersed on Fe nanoparticles, and then anchored on nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes to obtain Ir-SA@Fe@NCNT. Based on HAADF-STEM and EXAFS analyses, Ir was atomically dispersed in the nanotube structure, and no Ir-NPs were observed. OER tests were performed in a 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 solution under O2 flow. The overpotential of Ir-SA@Fe@NCNT was 250 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and the TOF was 4.4 s−1. The mass-specific activity of the catalyst was 13.7 A mgIr −1, which was 20 times higher than that of Ir-NP@Fe@NCNT and 1370 times higher than that of IrO2. The double-layer capacitance test calculation showed that the catalyst had a larger ECSA, indicating a higher utilization rate of Ir atoms, thus obtaining outstanding catalytic activity. Combined with the potential cycle of RHE and 12-h OER test, the activity of the catalyst remained unchanged, indicating that Ir-SA@Fe@NCNT had good stability (Fig. 15(b)). The development of Ni SACs for the OER can effectively minimize the use of rare and expensive Ru. Li and co-workers [160], for the first time, reported that a Ni SAC synthesized using a NaCl template is a Ni-O-G SAC with high OER activity, coordinated to oxygen atoms on graphene-like carbon. SEM and TEM images showed a three-dimensional pore framework, indicating that the desired catalyst structure was successfully produced using the NaCl template. In the FT-EXAFS spectrum, there was a peak at 1.6 Å and no Ni–Ni coordination peak at 2.6 Å, which indicated that Ni was only bonded to oxygen and that the Ni in the Ni-O-G SAC was monatomically distributed. In the evaluation of OER performance, the overpotential of the Ni-O-G SAC was 224 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which was lower than that of the pure nickel-based catalyst reported at that time. The TOF values at 300 and 350 mV were 1.44 and 2.81 s−1, respectively, which were the optimal values in the OER reported at that time. In the HAADF-STEM images, after the long-term endurance test at 400 mV, Ni remained uniformly distributed on the carrier as single atoms, which reflects its excellent OER catalytic stability (Fig. 15(c)). The high-oxidation-state (+2.37 V) Ni atoms in the Ni–O bonds of the Ni-O-G SAC were important for the significant improvement of the OER performance. When compared with NiO (+1.84 V) and the Ni-N-G SAC (+1.57 V), the highly oxidized Ni sites in the Ni-O-G SAC had superior O-based adsorption capabilities, making it have the smallest energy barrier for *O formation (0.48 V). Improving the metal loading is the most basic way to optimize the catalytic performance of SACs. Wang et al. [161] reported an Ir loading in Ir SACs (Ir-NiO) of up to 18 wt% when anchored on a NiO substrate. XRD, STEM, and DFT calculations showed that Ir atoms replaced Ni atoms in the NiO and were uniformly distributed on the outermost layer of the NiO matrix. In the OER electrochemical tests, with the increase in Ir loading in Ir-NiO (approximately 2 wt%–18 wt%), the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 decreased, and the overpotential of 18 wt% Ir-NiO was only 215 mV, showing the excellent OER activity of the 18 wt% Ir-NiO catalyst. The Tafel slope of 38 mV dec−1 and high current density of 114 mA cm−2 also confirmed the excellent OER activity. The DFT calculations also showed that during the substitution process, Ir atoms not only become the active center of the OER, but also greatly improve the OER performance of NiO by introducing additional electrons (Fig. 15(d)). This was due to the strong binding of the Ir atom that was in the +4 oxidation state to the reaction intermediate and the effect of the two electrons provided by Ir4+ on the oxidation state of Ni in NiO. The 10-h durability test and subsequent STEM characterization showed that 18 wt% Ir-NiO had high stability, and the insertion of the outermost Ir atom was key in improving the stability. The two metal sites in bimetallic SACs synergistically play different roles in electrocatalytic reactions. Greta and co-workers [162] proposed a simple molecule-based tailoring strategy to synthesize a highly loaded (5.6 wt%) bimetallic NiFe SAC (NiFe-CNG) anchored on g-C3N4 via a two-step growth mechanism. In the OER performance test (Fig. 15(e)), the researchers found that adjusting the Ni/Fe molar ratio effectively regulated the OER kinetics, and the catalytic activity was optimal when the ratio was 7:3 (at an overpotential of 270 mV). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy results showed that the synergy of Ni and Fe was beneficial to the OER at high and low potentials (Fig. 15(f)). After in situ EXAFS analysis and comparison (Fig. 15(g)), it was concluded that the formation of a Ni–O–Fe bond in NiFe-CNG improved the OER performance. 4.2 Application of metal SACs in the HER HER is a reaction in the electrolysis of water for generating clean H2, which is usually performed in acidic media [163]. Pt is considered to be the best HER catalyst, but the high cost and scarcity of Pt hinder the development of Pt-based catalysts for HER. The development of cheaper metal-based SACs can effectively solve this problem. As shown in Table 2 , metal-based SACs, such as Co, Ir, and Ru, have also been developed in the field of HER catalysis in recent years [20,42,142,144,145, 164–177]. Zheng et al. [178] reported a high HER performance of single-atom Co arrays on distorted 1T MoS2 (SA Co–D 1T MoS2) that was obtained by covalently binding SA Co–D 1T MoS2 nanosheets through electrochemical CV leaching, and its metal loading was up to 3.54 wt%. The Co–Co bond was transformed into a Co–S covalent bond in the synthesis. HAADF-STEM imaging showed that Co was uniformly dispersed at the top of the Mo atom on the MoS2 plane. In the electrochemical test at 10 mA cm−2 in a 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 solution, the overpotential (η = 42 mV) and Tafel slope (32 mV dec−1) indicated that the catalyst had excellent HER activity, which was equivalent to that of commercial Pt/C. The HER polarograms of several materials (viz., 2H MoS2, 1T MoS2, Co NDs/MoS2, and SA Co-D 1T MoS2, without and with SCN− ions) were compared and analyzed (Fig. 16(a) ). The synergy between the single Co atoms and MoS2 phase transition process led to the high HER activity of SA Co-D 1T MoS2, and the SA Co played a leading role. The high catalytic stability of SA Co-D 1T MoS2 was determined via linear sweep voltammetry and 100 mV static overpotential long-term test. Graphdiyne (GDY) as a SAC support can provide a good coordination environment for Pt atoms and favors high HER catalytic activity. In GDY, C atoms interact strongly with Pt, making it easy to anchor Pt on GDY. Lu and co-workers [179] reported SA Pt with different coordination environments (five-coordinate Pt-GDY1 and four-coordinate Pt-GDY2) prepared via wet chemical synthesis with graphite diacetylene as the carrier. When compared with SA Pt-GDY1, the Pt atom in SA Pt-GDY2 was in a more positive valence state (Fig. 16(b)), and its 5d orbital did not occupy the highest density. The electrochemical properties were compared horizontally, and the performances of SA Pt-GDY1 and SA Pt-GDY2 were better than that of commercial Pt/C in the polarization curve, mass activity, and Tafel curve (Fig. 16(c)). Among them, SA Pt-GDY2 showed the best HER catalytic activity. At the same time, the C2-Pt-Cl2 coordination structure in SA Pt-GDY2 made the Pt atoms bind strongly to the support surface, resulting in the easy formation of the desired structure and better catalyst stability. DFT calculations showed that the appropriate Gibbs free energy for hydrogen adsorption by Pt and the high density of unoccupied states of the 5d orbitals of Pt atoms were the main causes of the improved HER catalytic activity. Weakly electronegative P can be used to replace N in MN4, and the structure could be optimized to control the active sites in the catalyst [180]. Wang et al. [181] designed a strategy for the synthesis of carbon-loaded Co SACs (Co-SA/P-in situ) with a Co1P1N3 interfacial structure by combining a wet chemical method with thermal decomposition, and used one P atom and three N atoms to anchor Co in the framework. The experimental characterization results showed that the mass percentage of Co in the prepared Co-SA/P-in situ was 1.6 wt%. Soft XANES analysis showed that Co-N/P bonds formed in the Co-SA/P-in situ sample. When compared with other catalysts, Co-SA/P-in situ had the smallest Tafel slope, indicating a better HER performance. The TOF value and overpotential measured in the acidic solution were also better than those of some other non-precious-metal-based catalysts. DFT calculations showed that the Co1P1N3 coordination structure, formed through the synergy between the active Co center and the P or N atoms, exhibited the most suitable energy barrier in the two hydrogen evolution pathways of the HER, which improved HER catalytic activity. In the stability test, the catalytic activity did not significantly decrease after 1000 times CV and the overpotential was unchanged after 30 h, which confirmed that the catalyst was highly stable. Ir-SA@Fe@NCNT, which was synthesized by Cai and co-workers [159], not only exhibited good OER performance, but also showed excellent HER performance. In a 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 electrolyte under a deoxygenated-N2 atmosphere, the catalyst had a lower overpotential than commercial Pt/C. Researchers believed that this catalyst was a suitable cathode electrocatalyst for water splitting in a solid polymer electrolyte. Through the calculation of mass fraction (Fig. 16(d)) and CV testing, the catalyst had high activity and a high ECSA, which led to the excellent HER activity. Based on durability test results (Fig. 16(e)), the high stability of Ir-SA@Fe@NCNT stems from the strong interaction between Fe and Ir. The introduction of strongly electronegative metal atoms into Ru SACs with poor stability can adjust the electronic structure of the catalyst and increase the active potential, thereby improving the performance of Ru-based catalysts. Lei et al. [182] reported bimetallic RuNi SACs on modified MoS2 (RuNi SACs-MoS2) synthesized via hydrothermal treatment, in which highly electronegative Ni was beneficial to the introduction of Ru atoms into MoS2 and effectively improved the catalytic activity of Ru in the HER. According to the HER overpotential and Tafel slope, the catalyst exhibited better catalytic activity and faster kinetics than commercial Pt/C. Moreover, the durability test results showed that the low Ru concentration in the electrolyte and stable LSV curve indicated excellent catalyst stability. DFT calculations and Bader analysis showed that S-Ni and Ru in Ru/Ni-MoS2 were favored H and OH adsorption, respectively, which further promoted the HER catalytic process (Fig. 16(f)). Fe-N-C is generally considered as one of the best alternatives to noble metal catalysts in the context of HER, but has poor stability during the reaction. Atomic regulation of the Fe-N-C catalyst is a way to solve its poor stability. Shui et al. [183] prepared PtFe SACs by impregnating Pt atoms onto Fe atoms via the oxygen of the Fe-N-C center (Fig. 16(g)), where the Pt1*O2*Fe1-N4 configuration can promote H adsorption and desorption. When compared with catalysts with different components, the LSV test results showed that 2.1 wt% Pt1@Fe-N-C exhibited the best performance (Fig. 16(h)). In acidic PEMFC testing, Pt1@Fe-N-C with a 3 mg cm−2 loading showed the best activity and that the degradation rate decreased significantly. In the 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 HER test, Pt1@Fe-N-C, with an onset overpotential of 15 mV and Tafel slope of 42 mV dec−1 (Fig. 16(i)), exhibited superior HER catalytic activity than Fe-N-C and Pt/C. The chronopotentiometry result of Pt1@Fe-N-C also showed superior long-term stability in the HER. 4.3 Application of metal SACs in the ORR ORR is usually carried out in two ways: 4e− (O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → H2O) and 2e− (O2 + 2H+ + 2e− → H2O2) to obtain H2O and H2O2, respectively [155,184]. The main difference in the above reaction processes is whether the O–O bond is broken or not. Because of the slow kinetics of ORR reaction, it is very important to develop SACs with high ORR activity [185,186]. According to the volcano diagram simulated using DFT, Pt catalysts typically exhibit suitable oxygen adsorption energies and are theoretically the best ORR catalysts. As shown in Table 3 , more noble metal-based SACs, including Pt, Ru, Ag, etc., have been developed and optimized in recent years when compared with bulk and nanocatalysts. Furthermore, many non-noble metal SACs (Table 3) have exhibited ORR activities that are not inferior to those of Pt-based catalysts and received extensive research attention [187–199]. Wang et al. [200] reported SACs based on transition metals (Fe, Pd, Co, and Mn) anchored on carbon nanotubes (CNT) (Fig. 17(a) ). By controlling the coordination elements (O, C, and N), the ORR of the 2e− selective reduction of H2O2 and the 4e− selective reduction of H2O can be controlled. Among them, the Fe-C-O selective path generated H2O2, which showed the best ORR performance. Atom probe tomography (APT) indicated that Fe was atomically dispersed on the carbon nanotubes. According to the rotating ring-disc electrode test, in an alkaline environment of a 1 mol L−1 KOH solution, the half slope potential of Fe-CNT was 0.822 V vs. RHE, and the selectivity to H2O2 was larger than 95% (Fig. 17(c)). The catalytic performance (activity and selectivity) of Fe–CNT increased with an increase in the Fe content. However, when Fe clusters appeared (Fig. 17(b)) at an Fe loading of 0.2 atom%, the catalytic performance decreased rapidly. This showed the superior catalytic performance of isolated single-atom Fe active sites in the selective production of H2O2. At the same time, Fe-CNT also exhibited stable and high H2O2 selectivity, which was related to the good stability of the coordination structure of its active site.
