DFT calculations revealed that the O and C atoms in the Fe–C–O motif were beneficial in the selective generation of H2O2 and were very active, which was consistent with the APT results. For optimizing the catalytic performance of the ORR, changing the morphology of the catalyst is a direction worth exploring. By engineering the morphology, the active sites of the catalyst can be exposed more, which enhances catalytic activity. Hou et al. [187] designed the eaves structure to synthesize Fe SACs using silica-mediated MOFs as a template, which enabled the catalyst to have exposed metal active sites with high utilization. HAADF-STEM imaging confirmed that Fe existed as an isolated monatomic site in the catalyst. ORR testing was performed in a 1 mol L−1 KOH solution. Fe SACs exhibited an excellent onset potential and half slope potential, indicating that this structure was conducive to the transport of sensing materials; the half slope potential was the same as that of commercial Pt/C (0.85 V vs. RHE), indicating equivalent catalytic activity (Fig. 17(d)), which was superior to that of most non-noble metal catalysts reported in the literature (the TOF was the highest among Pt-free ORR catalysts [201–203]) [204–220]. According to DFT calculations, the excellent catalytic activity comes from the Fe-N4-C structure. Additionally, the test results in an alkaline environment showed that the Fe SAC had excellent catalytic durability and methanol toxicity resistance. In addition to improving the morphology, the preparation of SACs with high metal loading is a direct way to optimize catalytic performance. Qiao and co-workers [221] synthesized a high-loading (>10 wt%) Mo SAC (Mo1/OSG-H) via the pyrolysis of the MgO template, and the catalyst had O and S double-coordination structures. XPS, XANES, and EXAFS analyses (Fig. 17(e)) showed that the valence states of Mo in the catalyst were Mo4+/Mo6+ at a ratio of 1:4. In the electrochemical test of the RRDE, Mo1/OSG-H exhibited fast ORR kinetics, a low Tafel slope (54.7 mV dec−1), and high H2O2 selectivity (>95%). DFT showed that the local coordination structure could significantly affect the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. Non-noble metal catalysts usually have poor stability in the ORR. With a low activity in the Fenton reaction, Cr-based SACs can reduce the influence of oxidation corrosion, which is beneficial to catalytic stability in the ORR. Ge and co-workers [222] reported Cr SACs (Cr/N/C-950) (Fig. 18(a) ) synthesized via host-guest interactions with the ZIF skeleton as the carrier after pyrolysis, in which the large cavity and mesoporous structure favored the catalytic reaction (Fig. 18(b)). The R-space least squares fitting results showed that the Cr-N4 configuration in the catalyst favored the ORR. In the horizontal comparison of catalytic activity, the researchers found that the coexistence of Cr and N significantly improved the ORR activity. The accelerated degradation test (ADT) of 20000 potential cycles (Fig. 18(c)) showed that the half slope potential of Cr/N/C-950 decreased by 15 mV and that Cr/N/C-950 exhibited excellent catalytic stability during chronoamperometry. Multifunctional catalysts can be applied to different catalytic reactions by only changing the catalytic reaction environment, which effectively reduces the development and production costs of different catalysts. This is very attractive for the development of noble metal-based catalysts with high catalytic performance but of high cost. Some Ru-based SACs with the Ru-N4 coordination structure have been shown to exhibit excellent catalytic performance in various reactions, such as the OER, ORR, and CO2RR [52,145,223–225]. The research group of Liu has developed trifunctional Ru-based SACs (Ru-SA/Ti3C2T x ) for the HER, OER, and ORR [226]. Ultrathin Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets with high surface area and unique surface defects were used as SACs carriers. The single atom Ru was anchored to the oxygen-containing groups on the surface of the carrier to form a Ru-O2 coordination structure. HAADF-STEM and Fourier-transform EXAFS analyses (Fig. 18(d)) showed that uniformly dispersed Ru SACs were successfully prepared. The ORR performance was evaluated in an O2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 HClO4 aqueous solution. Among them, Ru–SA/Ti3C2T x exhibited a highly consistent onset potential (E onset = 0.92 V) with Pt/C and a high half-slope potential (E 1/2 = 0.80 V) (Fig. 18(e)). The mass-specific activity (MA) of Ru–SA/Ti3C2T x (1.77 A mgRu −1) was 89 times higher than that of Pt/C (0.02 A mgPt −1). In the ORR stability test, Ru-SA/Ti3C2T x performed chronoamperometric electrolysis for up to 32 h at 0.6 V vs. RHE, indicating better durability than Pt/C. Meanwhile, the E 1/2 of Ru-SA/Ti3C2T x was only negatively shifted by 11 mV after 2000 cycles of the potential cycling test, further demonstrating the stability of the catalyst. In addition to the ORR performance test, Ru-SA/Ti3C2T x also showed excellent HER (η = 70 mV, 10 mA cm−1) and OER performances (Tafel slope = 37.9 mV dec−1) in N2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 HClO4. The formation of H2O was the potential-determining step (PDS) of the Ru-SA/ Ti3C2T x -catalyzed ORR with an energy barrier of only 0.33 eV, which was much lower than that of Ti3C2T x (1.23 eV; the formation of *OOH) (Fig. 18(f)). This further confirmed the uniform dispersion of single Ru atoms and that Ru–O2 enhanced the ORR activity. 4.4 Application of metal SACs in the CO2RR CO2RR is a reduction reaction that consumes CO2 and produces CH4, CH3OH, and other chemical substances (Fig. 19 ), which will open up a new path for reducing CO2 and alleviate the global energy crisis [227]. The development of SACs with high selectivity and activity for the CO2RR can effectively reduce the overpotential and inhibit the competitiveness of the HER. Wang and co-workers [228] reported the synthesis of a Ni SAC with layered graphene oxide nanosheets as a carrier (Ni SACs-NGO) and Ni atoms uniformly anchored on the support vacancies. In the CO2RR electrochemical testing using a three-electrode electrolytic cell, the conversion rate of CO2 to CO exceeded 90% in a wide potential range, and the maximum faraday efficiency (FE) value of CO formation was greater than 95% (the overpotential was 550 mV) (Fig. 20(a) ). The researchers conducted a durability test for more than 20 h, including testing the species change of the active Ni center in the catalyst before and after the reaction (Fig. 20(b)). Ni SACs-NGO showed good long-term stability at a current density of 12 mA cm−2, with a CO selectivity of approximately 90%. The excellent structural stability shown in the TEM and ICP-AES results is the main reason for the excellent catalytic stability. CO2RR catalysts are potential catalysts for the chemical industry. However, owing to their poor applicability and unsuitable synthesis methods for large-scale production, it is necessary to explore ways for synthesizing CO2RR catalysts with wide applicability. Zhang et al. [229] designed a new ligand-mediated method to synthesize a series of metal SACs (M SACs) (M = Ni, Mn, Fe, Co, Cr, Cu, Zn, Ru, Pt, etc.) by complexing metal ions with 1,10-phenanthroline (Fig. 20(d)). Among them, Ni in the Ni SAC, in a valence state of approximately 0 to +2, has the Ni-N4 coordination structure (Fig. 20(c)). In the CO2RR test of the Ni SAC, the LSV curves obtained under Ar and CO2 atmospheres were compared. The results showed that the CO2 reduction potential of the Ni SAC was greater than that of hydrogen evolution, and this was also verified in the FE test (approximately 90%, –0.7 to –1.5 V vs. RHE). When compared with the FE values of CO of other metal based-SACs (M SACs) with the same metal loading at –1.2 V (Fig. 20(e)), it was speculated that the position of the d-band center of the Ni SAC promoted the CO2RR activity (Fig. 20(e)). Selective CO production in the CO2RR is very important for the synthesis of other products. Zn-based catalysts can be used for the selective production of CO in the CO2RR, but more research is needed to further optimize the catalytic performance. Song et al. [230] reported a carbon-supported nitrogen-anchored carbon black (BP 2000)-supported Zn SAC (ZnN x /C), in which Zn-based active site was mainly Zn-N4 (Fig. 20(f)). The synergistic effect of the doped N and Zn atoms influenced the catalytic performance. In LSV and product selectivity tests, ZnN x /C showed a remarkable activity in the CO2RR and high CO selectivity (95%) at an overpotential of 0.32 V. When compared with the ECSA results before and after the durability test (Fig. 20(g)), the researchers found that ZnN x /C maintained high catalytic activity during the long-term CO2RR. In the comparison of ZnN x /C active components at 30 and 75 h of the CO2RR, the almost unchanged N 1s XP spectra of ZnN x /C indicated that the high structural stability was the reason for the high catalytic durability, which was due to the durability of the Zn-N x structure during the CO2RR. Alcohol products with high economic value can be obtained via the CO2RR. Cu SACs obtained via a simple synthesis procedure at a high yield and with uniformly distributed Cu atoms can be used to produce alcohols via the CO2RR. He et al. [231] reported Cu-decorated through-hole carbon nanofibers (CuSAs/TCNFs), with a Cu loading of 1.3 wt%, layered porous structure, and Cu-N4 group, was synthesized via the double-solvent method (Fig. 20(h)). CuSAs/TCNFs were selective to methanol production and reach a maximum at –0.9 V vs. RHE (FE methanol = 44%). Additionally, the absence of methanol in the product of TCNFs indirectly proved that single Cu atoms are the active sites for the selective production of methanol. Furthermore, CuSAs/TCNFs exhibited excellent CO2RR performance, such as a low CO partial current density, high electrochemical active surface area (23.3 mF cm−2), stable current density with small attenuation after long-term electrolysis, and good mechanical properties, which can be used as a cathode electrode catalyst. According to DFT calculations (Fig. 20(i)), the reduction of the CO* intermediate to CH3OH was found to be an energy desorption process, which was related to the dispersed atomic point of Cu in the catalyst. In the study of SAC activity, the reasonable use of the carrier structure can reduce the aggregation of single atoms during catalyst preparation and optimize the active sites of the catalyst. Jiang et al. [232] reported a highly loaded Ni SAC (6.9 wt%) synthesized using porous, high surface defect three-dimensional microwave exfoliated graphene oxide (MEGO) as a carrier (Ni-N-MEGO), in which Ni was mainly anchored on the edge of the graphene steps, voids, or exposed surfaces (Fig. 20(j)), and was mainly coordinated with N to form Ni-N (83.8%). In the CO2RR electrochemical testing (Fig. 20(k)), Ni-N-MEGO showed excellent catalytic performances, such as a high current density, high CO yield (4.66 × 10−3 mmol cm−2 min−1, –0.55 V), and the highest FE value of 92.1%. By comparing the FE changes and DFT calculations before and after acid treatment (Fig. 20(l)), it was confirmed that the three-coordinated edge-anchored Ni–N structure (NiN3 and NiN2(NH2)) was the main active site for the CO2RR. 4.5 Application of metal SACs in the NRR NRR is generally considered a green pathway for the production of NH3 and nitrogen fixation [233]. However, during the reaction, there still exists some problems, such as the strong N-N triple bond and high overpotential, which hinder the NRR. Owing to the large number of active sites and unique structures, SACs are considered to have great potential in the NRR. Jung et al. [234] used DFT to study SACs based on defective graphene derivatives to improve ammonia production, where Ti@N4 and V@N4 had low overpotentials and high NRR selectivities. In the calculation and comparison of the metal atom binding energy (E b) and metal binding energy (E c), when E b > E c, the combination of atoms and carriers was more thermodynamically favored than aggregation. In the study of the NRR mechanism, SACs with ΔG PDS ≤ 1.0 eV had better or similar catalytic activity as the Ru(0001) stepped surface (0.98 eV). The protonation steps of 23 types of SACs (M@C3, M@C4, M@N3, and M@N4) with ΔG PDS ≤ 1.0 eV were analyzed (Fig. 21(a) ). Due to the lack of atomic ensembles and positive charge carried by the metal, unstable *H and *NH2 were generated at the top of the SACs, which significantly inhibited the HER. In industrial NH3 production, the problems of harsh reaction conditions and high costs need to be urgently solved. Therefore, cheap non-noble-metal-based catalysts have been widely studied for the NRR. Han et al. [235] designed and synthesized open porous Mo SAs supported on N-doped porous carbon (Mo SAs/NPC) (Fig. 21(b)), in which the three-dimensional interconnected carbon structure contributed to material migration during the electrocatalytic process. Based on ICP-AES analysis, the SAC had a high metal loading of 9.54 wt%. The strongest peak at 1.2 Å in the EXAFS spectrum shows that Mo was mainly combined with N and C in the catalyst. In the NRR, the NH3 yield of Mo SAs/NPC was highest at 0.3 V vs. RHE, and the corresponding NH3 concentration and FE value were 50.0 ± 5.3 μmol L−1 and 14.6 ± 1.6% (Fig. 21(c)) for 1 h, respectively, which were equivalent to those of the best NRR catalyst reported in the literature. Generally, SACs with good NRR performance need to be active in acidic media. The stable dispersed Fe in Fe-N4 is conducive to the formation of NH3 via the NRR under neutral conditions. Liu et al. [236] reported the synthesis of Fe SAs anchored on a nitrogen-doped carbon skeleton (Fe SAs-NC) via an improved hydrothermal method (Fig. 21(f)). ICP-AES revealed that the Fe content was 4.2 wt% in Fe SAs-NC. The specific surface area of Fe SAs-NC was 89.6 m2 g−1, which was conducive to exposing the catalytically active sites. In the NRR electrochemical testing, the Fe SAs-NC catalyst showed a high FE (18.6 ± 0.8%) and high yield (62.9 ± 2.7 μg h−1 cm−2) for NH3 formation at –0.4 V vs. RHE, and there was no N2H4 in the postpartum substance, indicating the high NRR activity and selectivity for NH3 formation of Fe SAs-NC. The HAADF-STEM images of Fe SAs-NC showed that the catalyst maintained the dispersion of the single Fe atoms after the 24-h NRR test, which was the main reason for its high catalytic stability. DFT calculations (Fig. 21(d)) showed that the excellent performance of Fe SAs-NC was due to the easy activation of N2 molecules on the high-density nitrogen coordination. The excellent properties of NC-based materials are beneficial for the immobilization of metal atoms and the regulation of SAC performance, and the excellent performance of Cu SAs loaded on NC for the NRR has been further explored. Wang et al. [237] synthesized a porous NC-supported Cu SAC (Cu SAs-NC) using simple surfactant. HAADF-STEM images and EDS spectra showed that the nitrogen-doped carbon layer exhibited a distorted porous structure, and the Cu atoms were uniformly dispersed in the catalyst. In the NRR, the average yield of NH3 from N2 electroreduction and the maximum FE (Fig. 21(e)) were 53.3 ± 1.86 μgNH3 h−1 mgcat −1 and 13.8%, respectively, and there was no N2H4 in the product, showing the excellent NRR activity and selectivity of Cu SAs-NC. According to the EELS data, Cu was possibly bound to 2-4 N atoms (Fig. 21(g)), thereby forming a Cu-N2 coordination structure and Cu-N4/C mixed coordination structure. Based on DFT, Cu-N2 with a proportion of approximately 20% had a strong binding ability to N2, which was conducive to the cleavage of the N≡N triple bond during the NRR. The prominent structure in SACs may lead to interfacial polarization, which has a great influence on catalytic performance. Zhang et al. [238] synthesized Fe SAs with a three-dimensional protruding structure dispersed on a monolayer MoS2 skeleton (Fe SAs-MoS2) via a two-step hydrothermal method (Figs. 21(h)–(i)). The EXAFS spectrum obtained showed that the coordination of Fe in the first shell was 3, and the average bond distance of Fe-S was 2.23 Å. Combined with HAADF-STEM images, it was shown that Fe did not enter the MoS2 lattice, which confirmed that the single Fe atoms coordinated with three adjacent Mo-S to form a prominent structure. In the determination of the electrochemistry, the best performance was obtained when the starting point of the NRR was –0.01 V. The total current density was 1.38 ± 0.12 mA cm−2 and NH3 yield was 97.5 ± 6 μg h−1 cm−2, which exceeded those of all MoS-based NRR electrocatalysts reported in the literature. The results of the comprehensive simulations and experiments showed that accelerated interfacial polarization leads to excellent and efficient NRR catalytic activity. 5 Conclusions and perspectives As emerging catalytic materials, SACs have shown great potential in the search for green energy owing to their low consumption and high catalytic performance. In recent years, after unremitting efforts, researchers have developed many strategies for synthesizing SACs, such as wet chemical methods, ALD, defect design, spatial confinement, high-temperature atom capture, and in situ pyrolysis. The synthesis strategies designed under the guidance of different ideas have prepared various SACs with better performances than those of traditional catalysts. Additionally, SACs have been developed for different electrocatalytic applications, such as the OER, HER, ORR, CO2RR, and NRR, and have demonstrated better catalytic activity, kinetics, and selectivity. It is gratifying that in the exploration of SAC synthesis methods and performance, our understanding of catalyst mechanisms is deepening, and the direction of catalyst characterization and performance research is becoming clearer. Although SACs have developed rapidly in recent years and have shown great potential in the field of electrochemical energy conversion, there are still many challenges for future development. The maximum atom utilization of SACs is unique in the field of catalysis; however, due to the high surface free energy of metallic single atoms, SACs easily agglomerate during catalytic reactions, and the catalytic performance becomes compromised. The traditional solution is to reduce metal loading to prevent the single atoms from gathering in the catalyst. However, this method greatly limits the catalytic performance and practical application of SACs. Therefore, it is necessary to develop SACs with a high metal loading, which can maintain the isolated dispersion of metal atoms during catalytic processes. Moreover, the desired dispersion of metallic active sites in SACs and uniformity of their surrounding coordination structures determine the preparation conditions that need to be precisely controlled. Typically, these controls can be easily achieved under laboratory conditions but are difficult in a large-scale industrial production environment. The applicability of laboratory-based synthesis method and conditions should be further simplified, such as the pipeline-like preparation strategy for SACs developed by He et al. [249], which only includes three steps of aqueous solution ultrasonic atomization, drying, and pyrolysis, and the method can also achieve considerable production in domestic production lines, covering a wide variety of metals. To date, most of the catalytic performance of SACs comes from electrochemical workstations or batteries in the laboratory. The study of synthesis strategy simplification is of great significance for the industrial production of high-performance SACs. Thereafter, the catalytic activity and product selectivity of catalysts on an industrial level should be improved. Finally, the structures of catalysts should be further optimized for different application scenarios. The research of SACs in the field of electrochemical energy conversion is still growing. In many studies involving electrochemical energy conversion reactions (HER, OER, ORR, CO2RR, and NRR), SACs mostly exhibit catalytic performance that is similar or superior to that of nanocatalysts, but there are still many shortcomings. The single active atomic sites of SACs contribute to the improvement of catalytic activity, but the single metal element always limits the development of the catalyst. The coordination of multi-metal elements can further optimize the electronic structure and coordination environment of the catalytic reaction. To date, bimetallic and multi-metal SACs have not been fully developed. This requires support from more advanced technologies in the preparation and characterization of SACs. Only under the conditions of precise control of the coordination environment and metal dispersion state of a single metal site, more detailed and scientific morphology, structural characterization, and theoretical analyses of catalysts can the development of bimetallic-based or multi-metal-based SACs be realized. The study of the coordination bonds formed through the bonding of the support surface with active metal atoms also needs attention. Due to the unique electronic structure and coordination environment, the same metal active sites exhibit different catalytic properties in different environments, which is also closely related to the different anchoring sites provided by the carrier. Carbon-based carriers and nitrogen-doped carbon carriers are often used to load single metal atoms. In recent years, researchers have studied how to exploit the physical and chemical properties of the carrier to improve the loading of single-atom catalysts, such as increasing the loading and avoiding agglomeration between single-atom sites. For the local coordination structures of active metal sites, such as M-N3, M-N4, and M-N5, there are few well-controlled preparation methods and exploration of the factors affecting catalytic performance. Furthermore, some other carriers, including metal-based carriers that are able to uniformly disperse stable single atoms can also cooperate with active sites to optimize catalytic performance. For example, Fe SACs obtained via the self-shrinking of the film surface exhibited surprising orderliness at the molecular level and superior ORR performance [250]. The intricate regulation helps to control the intrinsic state and surrounding environment of each loaded metal active site, which further improves the practicality of SACs. Most of the catalytic performance of current SACs comes from laboratory-based electrochemical workstations or batteries. In practical industrial production and application, the catalyst should not only show excellent catalytic activity, high product selectivity, and stable durability under experimental conditions, but also maintain considerable performance in a wide range. This requires a more elaborate regulation of the type and number of active sites and the surrounding coordination environment based on theoretical calculations to broaden the range of conditions that maintain the optimum performance of the catalyst, such as in the case of CoCu bimetallic SACs with up to 483 mA cm−2 of j CO [251]. The broadening of the scope of catalytic conditions can lay a solid foundation for the future application of SACs. The simple and uniform structure of SACs provides the convenience of simulation for the study of electrocatalytic mechanisms, which is helpful for exploring the reaction principle of each electrochemical energy conversion process and promote the optimization and truth-seeking of reaction mechanisms, such as the development of traditional mechanism AEM to LOM for the OER. This is of great significance for guiding the practical development of more efficient and stable SACs. With the wide attention and continuous development of SACs, more designs and fabrications will be optimized, and homogeneous single-atom catalysts with high metal loadings and high electrocatalytic performances will be further developed. Prof. Gao-Ren Li (College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University) received his B.A. degree from East China University of Technology in 2000, and Ph.D. degree from Sun Yat-sen University in 2005. From September 2005 to September 2021, he worked in School of Chemistry, Sun Yat-sen Universtiy. Since October 2021, he has been working in College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University. His current research interests mainly focus on electrocatalysis, especially water splitting and electrochemical conversion of CO2.

coredata.dc:description: Singe-atom catalysts (SACs), as heterogeneous catalysts, have attracted increasing attention in recent years owing to their numerous advantages in the field of electrocatalysis, such as a high atom-utilization rate and unique structural characteristics. In this review, we introduce various preparation methods for obtaining SACs based on top-down and bottom-up synthesis strategies and the corresponding research progress made in recent years. We also focus on the electrocatalytic applications of SACs containing noble metals (Pt, Pd, Ir, etc.) and non-noble metals (Fe, Cu, Co, etc.) in the oxygen evolution reaction, hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen reduction reaction, carbon dioxide reduction reaction, and nitrogen reduction reaction. Finally, the future challenges and prospects of monatomic catalysts are also discussed.

coredata.dc:title: Syntheses and applications of single-atom catalysts for electrochemical energy conversion reactions
